title: Daily Hustle

modules.title: Week 1: Foundations
modules.description: Establish the core practices that make daily execution possible

contentBlocks.content:
Before Everything, One Thing

Most productivity systems fail because they ask you to do more. Daily Hustle asks you to do less‚Äîbut to do it completely.

Today we introduce the One Thing Principle: the practice of identifying and protecting the single most important action of your day.

contentBlocks.title: Core Idea
contentBlocks.content: Your attention is finite. Scatter it across ten tasks and you'll complete none with excellence. Focus it on one, and you'll build momentum that carries forward.

The Practice

Before opening any app, before checking any message, answer this question: What is the one thing that, if completed today, would make everything else easier or unnecessary?

items: Identify your One Thing for today
Write it on paper (not an app)
Set a 90-minute block to work on it
Protect this block like a meeting with your most important client

contentBlocks.prompt: What usually competes for your attention first thing in the morning? How does that affect the rest of your day?

contentBlocks.content:
Creating Space Before Action

A container holds what you put in it. Your morning is a container for your day. What you put in it first determines everything that follows.

contentBlocks.title: Try This
contentBlocks.content: Tomorrow morning, do not touch your phone for the first 60 minutes after waking. Use this time for your One Thing work only.
The Morning Container isn't about waking earlier (though that helps). It's about protecting the first hours of your day from reactive work‚Äîemails, messages, other people's priorities.

contentBlocks.question: What makes the morning hours particularly valuable for focused work?

options.text: Others haven't started demanding your attention yet
Coffee works better in the morning

feedback.correct: Exactly. The morning is precious because you haven't yet been pulled into reactive mode. Once you check email or messages, you're responding to someone else's agenda.
feedback.incorrect: Consider what makes morning different from afternoon in terms of what's demanding your attention.

contentBlocks.prompt: What currently fills your first hour after waking? List everything, honestly.

contentBlocks.content:
Endings Matter More Than Beginnings

How you end your workday determines how you start the next one. Without a clean shutdown, open loops follow you into evening, stealing rest and creating morning anxiety.

The 5-Minute Shutdown

At the end of each workday, take exactly 5 minutes to:

contentBlocks.title: Common Mistake
contentBlocks.content: Don't skip the verbal shutdown. It sounds odd, but saying 'Shutdown complete' creates a psychological boundary that prevents work thoughts from bleeding into personal time.

contentBlocks.prompt: How do you currently transition from work to rest? What thoughts tend to follow you into the evening?

modules.title: Week 2: Building Momentum
modules.description: Develop consistency through daily tracking and intentional friction

contentBlocks.content:
Consistency Compounds

A streak isn't about perfection‚Äîit's about showing up. When you execute your One Thing for multiple consecutive days, something shifts. The practice becomes identity.

contentBlocks.title: The Math of Streaks
contentBlocks.content: 7 days creates a habit. 21 days creates identity. 66 days creates automation. We're building toward identity.
Track your streak visually. A physical calendar with X marks. A row of dots on paper. Something you can see without opening a device.

contentBlocks.prompt: What's the longest streak you've maintained for any habit? What broke it?

contentBlocks.content:
Make Distraction Difficult

Willpower is limited. Environment design is not. Today we redesign your environment to make focus the path of least resistance.

The Friction Audit

List every source of distraction in your work environment. For each one, add friction:

items: Phone: Keep in another room during focus blocks
Email: Log out of email app on phone
Browser: Use a blocker for social sites during work
Physical: Face away from high-traffic areas

contentBlocks.title: Pro Move
contentBlocks.content: The night before, set up your workspace for morning focus. Open the document you'll work on. Close everything else. Make starting frictionless.

contentBlocks.prompt: What's your biggest source of distraction? What friction could you add to make it harder to access?

modules.title: Week 3: Sustainable Practice
modules.description: Integrate the practices into lasting daily rhythms

contentBlocks.content:
Reflection as Practice

Each week, take 30 minutes to review. Not to optimize‚Äîto understand. What worked? What didn't? What does next week need?

items: Note patterns in energy and focus

contentBlocks.prompt: Looking back at this week: what one adjustment would have the biggest impact on your focus?

contentBlocks.content:
The Practice Continues

Day 21 isn't the end‚Äîit's the beginning. You now have a framework for daily execution. The question is: will you maintain it?

contentBlocks.title: After the Course
contentBlocks.content: Continue the One Thing practice. Continue the Morning Container. Continue the Shutdown Ritual. These aren't techniques to learn and discard‚Äîthey're practices to maintain.
The goal was never productivity for its own sake. The goal is a life where you do meaningful work, consistently, without burning out. That requires ongoing attention to attention itself.

contentBlocks.prompt: What will you commit to maintaining after this course ends? Be specific.

faqs.question: How long does each lesson take?
faqs.answer: Each daily lesson takes between 5 and 12 minutes. Some days include practical exercises that may take additional time if you choose to go deeper.

faqs.question: Can I do multiple lessons in one day?
faqs.answer: We recommend one lesson per day. The spacing is intentional‚Äîit gives each practice time to integrate before adding the next. That said, you have lifetime access and can revisit lessons anytime.

faqs.question: What if I miss a day?
faqs.answer: Just continue the next day. Don't try to 'catch up' by doing multiple lessons. The streak resets, but the practice continues.

faqs.question: Is there a refund policy?
faqs.answer: Yes. If Daily Hustle isn't right for you, request a full refund within 14 days of purchase. No questions asked.

faqs.question: How long do I have access?
faqs.answer: Lifetime access. Complete at your own pace, revisit anytime.

faqs.question: Is this available in other languages?
faqs.answer: Currently available in English. Italian version coming soon.

title: Focus Foundations
subtitle: A 7-day introduction to attention management
description: New to attention work? Focus Foundations provides a gentle introduction to the core concepts of focus management. In just 7 days, you'll understand why focus is hard in the modern world and learn the fundamental practices that make deeper work possible.

instructor.name: Marco Bellini
instructor.bio: Course creator based in Milan, focused on helping people rebuild their relationship with attention.

outcomes.text: Understand why focus is increasingly difficult
Start a simple daily focus practice

contentBlocks.content:
The Attention Economy

Your attention is the most valuable resource in the modern economy. Every app, notification, and feed is designed to capture and hold it. Understanding this is the first step to reclaiming control.

One Thing at a Time

Multitasking is a myth. What we call multitasking is actually rapid task-switching‚Äîand each switch costs mental energy and reduces quality.

faqs.question: Is this course really free?
faqs.answer: Yes, completely free. No credit card required. It's our introduction to the Daily Hustle approach.

faqs.question: What should I do after this?
faqs.answer: If you want to go deeper, Daily Hustle is the natural next step‚Äîa 21-day structured practice that builds on these foundations.

contentBlocks.content:
Start Smaller Than You Think

The biggest barrier to creative consistency isn't time‚Äîit's resistance. Today we establish your Minimum Creative Act: the smallest possible creative action you can take daily.

faqs.question: Do I need to be a professional creative?
faqs.answer: No. This course is for anyone who wants to create consistently‚Äîwhether you're a professional, hobbyist, or just starting out.

modules.title: Cutting Through Complexity

contentBlocks.content:
What's Actually Unclear?

Before we can create clarity, we need to identify where confusion lives. The Clarity Audit surfaces the specific decisions, priorities, and processes that are draining your mental energy.

faqs.question: Is this for entrepreneurs only?
